title: Modelling multiple time series via common factors

references.title: A canonical analysis of multiple time series.
references.raw: Box, G. & Tiao, G. (1977). A canonical analysis of multiple time series. Biometrika, 64, 355-365.

references.raw: Engle, R. & Watson, M. (1981). A one-factor multivariate time series model of metropolitan wage rates. Journal of the American Statistical Association, 76, 774-781.

Discussion Paper No. EM/90/216, Suntory-Toyota International Centre for Economics and Related Disciplines, London School of Economics, Houghton street, London WC2A 2AE.

references.raw: Reinsel, G.C. & Velu, R.P. (1998). Multivariate Reduced Rank Regression. Springer, New York.

references.title: Nonstationary dynamic factor analysis.
references.raw: Pe˜ na, D. & Poncela, P. (2006). Nonstationary dynamic factor analysis. Journal of Statistical Planning and Inference, 136, 1237-1257.

references.raw: Press, W.H., Teukolsky, S.A., Vetterling, W.T. & Flannery, B.P. (1992). Numerical Recipes in C. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge.

references.title: On a measure of lack of ﬁt in time series models.
references.raw: Ljung, G.M. & Box, G.E.P. (1978). On a measure of lack of ﬁt in time series models. Biometrika, 65, 297-303.

references.title: Strong law for a mixing sequence,
references.raw: Chen, X. R. & Wu, Y. H. (1989). Strong law for a mixing sequence, Acta Math. Appl. Sinica. 5, 367-371.

references.title: The dynamic factor analysis of economic time series models.
references.raw: Geweke, J. (1977). The dynamic factor analysis of economic time series models. In “Latent Variables in Socio-Economic Models”, eds. D.J. Aigner & A.S. Goldberger. North-Holland, Amsterdam, pp.365-383.

references.title: The generalized dynamic factor model: identiﬁcation and estimation.
references.raw: Forni, M., Hallin, M., Lippi, M. & Reichlin, L. (2000). The generalized dynamic factor model: identiﬁcation and estimation. Review of Econ. Statist. 82, 540-554.

references.title: Time Series Data Analysis and Theory, Extended edition, HoldenDay,
references.raw: Brillinger, D.R. (1981). Time Series Data Analysis and Theory, Extended edition, HoldenDay, San Francisco.

abstract: We propose a new method for estimating common factors of multiple time series. One distinctive feature of the new approach is that it is applicable to some nonstationary time series. The unobservable, nonstationary factors are identified by expanding the white noise space step by step, thereby solving a high-dimensional optimization problem by several low-dimensional sub-problems. Asymptotic properties of the estimation are investigated. The proposed methodology is illustrated with both simulated and real datasets

The unobservable, nonstationary factors are identified by expanding the white noise space step by step, thereby solving a high-dimensional optimization problem by several low-dimensional sub-problems.
